text: [Music]
[Applause]
[Music]
hello I'm Dale a cloud support engineer
here at the AWS office in Cape Town
today I'm going to show you how to view
the total storage available to use and
the total storage use for your Amazon
Aurora ml compatible Edition DB cluster
let's get
started a my SQL DB cluster volumes
automatically scale up as the amount of
data in database grows the maximum size
is 128 tbes or tib for all Aurora myql
version 3 versions 2.09 and higher and
64 trb for previous
versions you can monitor the storage
usage through Amazon cloudwatch Matrix
and the Amazon relational database
service Matrix let's first look at the
Aurora volume bytes left total
metric open the cloudwatch console and
then go to the Met
section under all metrics select
RDS and then select DB cluster
identifier in the search box enter aota
volume byes left
total and then select the metric this
metric shows the remaining available
storage space for the cluster volume in
bites as data grows this value decreases
which indicates you are approaching the
size limit note that the magic is
available only for aora myql compatible
version
2.4.5 or higher next let's look at the
volume pites used metric to see the
actual storage consumed open the Aus
console and then select your AWS region
go to
databases and then select your Aurora
myql DB
cluster on the monitoring tab search for
volume
used or selected from the
list now you see the graph of the
storage consumed by your DB cluster over
time in pites the Aurora database
service uses separate local storage for
temporary files like logs and data used
during queries which can be monitored
using the local free storage cloudwatch
metric but this doesn't apply to aora
serverless version tool for more
information see the knowledge Center
article Linked In the video description
you can also view the Aurora volume by
left total metric here and now you know
how to view the total storage available
to use and the total storage used for
your aora ml DB
cluster thanks for watching and happy
cloud computing from all of us here at
AWS
[Music]
[Applause]
[Music]
[Music]
